standard_metadata.standard_description: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Add and subtract fractions word problems (same denominator)

question.content: Lincoln wants to mix $\dfrac{3}{8}$ of a liter of red paint with $\dfrac{7}{8}$ of a liter of blue paint to make purple paint.  **How many liters of purple paint will Lincoln make by mixing the two colors?**     liters

hints.content: To find the amount of $\purpleD{\text{purple}}$ paint, we can add the liters of $\redD{\text{red}}$ paint to the liters of $\blueD{\text{blue}}$ paint:  $\redD{\dfrac{3}{8}} + \blueD{\dfrac{7}{8}}$

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each part labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket above the first three parts of the first bar is labeled three-eighths. A curved bracket above the remaining five parts of the first bar and the first two parts of the second bar is labeled seven-eighths. Together, the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled three-eighths plus seven-eighths.

hints.content: Lincoln will make ${\dfrac{10}{8}}$ liters of $\purpleD{\text{purple}}$ paint.  This can also be written as ${\dfrac{5}{4}}$ liters or ${1\dfrac{1}{4}}$ liters.

question.content: Travis just started high school, and he wants to manage his time wisely.  He schedules $\dfrac{3}{2}$ hours each day for homework, $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of an hour each day for chores at home, and $\dfrac{17}{2}$ hours each day for sleep.  ** How many hours each day are scheduled for these activities?**   hours

hints.content: To find out the total hours Travis has scheduled for these activities, we can add the fractions:  $\blueD{\dfrac{3}{2}} + \greenD{\dfrac{1}{2}} + \maroonD{\dfrac{17}{2}}$

images.alt: Eleven equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts, each part labeled one-half. A curved bracket above all the parts of the first bar and the first part of the second bar is labeled three-halves. A curved bracket above the second part of the second bar is labeled one-half. A curved bracket above all the parts of the third to tenth bars and the first part of the eleventh bar is labeled seventeen-halves. Together, the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled three-halves plus one-half plus seventeen-halves.

hints.content: Travis schedules ${\dfrac{21}{2}}$ hours each day for these activities.  This can also be written as ${10\dfrac{1}{2}}$ hours.

question.content: Bjorn is baking his favorite dessert.  The recipe calls for $\dfrac{5}{8}$ of a stick of butter, but he wants to double the recipe.    **How much butter will Bjorn need?**   sticks

hints.content: To find out how many sticks of butter Bjorn needs, we can add the fraction $\dfrac{5}{8}$ twice:  $\blueD{\dfrac{5}{8}} + \greenD{\dfrac{5}{8}}$

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each part labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket above the first five parts of the first bar is labeled five-eighths. A curved bracket above the remaining three parts of the first bar and the first two parts of the second bar is labeled five-eighths. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled five-eighths plus five-eighths.

hints.content: Bjorn will need  $\dfrac{{10}}{8}$ of a stick of butter.  This can also be written as $\dfrac{{5}}{4}$ sticks or ${1\dfrac{1}{4}}$ sticks.

question.content: Tyler and Katie started a lemonade stand to raise money.  They donated $\dfrac{2}{10}$ of their profits to their school library, $\dfrac{1}{10}$ to the animal shelter, and $\dfrac{4}{10}$ to the food bank.  They saved the rest to buy materials for their next project.  **What fraction of their profits did Tyler and Katie donate?**

hints.content: To find out what fraction of the profits were donated, we can add the fractions:  $\blueD{\dfrac{2}{10}} + \green{\dfrac{1}{10}} + \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{10}}$

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 10 equal parts, each part labeled one-tenth. A curved bracket above the first two parts is labeled two-tenths. A curved bracket above the next part is labeled one-tenth. A curved bracket above the next four parts is labeled four tenths. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bar are labeled two-tenths plus one-tenth plus four-tenths.

hints.content: Tyler and Katie donated $\dfrac{{7}}{10}$ of their profits.

question.content: One glass of milk gives you $\dfrac{3}{10}$ of the recommended amount of calcium per day.    **$3$ glasses of milk will give you what fraction of the recommended amount of calcium per day?**

hints.content: To find the fraction of recommended calcium from $3$ glasses of milk, we can add the fraction you will get from each glass of milk $3$ times:   $\blueD{\dfrac{3}{10}} + \green{\dfrac{3}{10}} + \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}$

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 10 equal parts, each part labeled one-tenth. A curved bracket above the first three parts is labeled three-tenths. A curved bracket above the next three parts is labeled three-tenths. A curved bracket above the next three parts is labeled three-tenths. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-tenths plus three-tenths plus three-tenths.

hints.content: If you drink $3$ glasses of milk a day, you will get $\dfrac{{9}}{10}$of the recommended amount of calcium.

question.content: Joanna is carrying her books to school in her backpack.  Her library book weighs $\dfrac{3}{8}$ of a kilogram, her science book weighs $\dfrac{11}{8}$ kilograms, and her math book weighs $\dfrac{5}{8}$ kilograms.    **How much do Joanna's books weigh altogether?**   kilograms

hints.content: To find out how many kilograms the books weigh altogether, we can add their weights:  $\blueD{\dfrac{3}{8}} + \greenD{\dfrac{11}{8}}+ \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}$

images.alt: Three equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each part labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket above the first three parts of the first bar is labeled three-eighths. A curved bracket above the remaining five parts of the first bar and the first six parts of the second bar is labeled eleven-eighths. A curved bracket above the last two parts of the second bar and the first three parts of the third bar is labeled five-eighths. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-eighths plus eleven-eighths plus five-eighths.

hints.content: Joanna's books weigh $\dfrac{{19}}{8}$ kilograms.  This can also be written as ${2\dfrac{3}{8}}$ kilograms.

question.content: A child's ladder is made of $3$ sections.  Each section is $\dfrac{3}{4}$ meters long.    **How long is the ladder when all $3$ sections are extended to make one ladder?**   meters

hints.content: To find out the total length of the ladder, we can add the lengths of the $3$ sections:  $\blueD{\dfrac{3}{4}} + \greenD{\dfrac{3}{4}} + \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}}$

images.alt: Three equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each part labeled one-fourth. A curved bracket above the first three parts of the first bar is labeled three-fourths. A curved bracket above the remaining part of the first bar and the first two parts of the second bar is labeled three-fourths. A curved bracket above the remaining parts of the second bar and the first part of the third bar is labeled three-fourths. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled three-fourths plus three-fourths plus three-fourths.

hints.content: The length of the child's ladder is $\dfrac{{9}}{4}$ meters.  This can also be written as ${2\dfrac{1}{4}}$ meters.

question.content: Winnie and Kevin like to create their own triathlon courses to challenge each other.  Last weekend, Winnie created a course that included a swim of $\dfrac{5}{4}$ kilometers, a bike ride of $\dfrac{95}{4}$ kilometers, and a run of $\dfrac{21}{4}$ kilometers.  **How long was the course Winnie created?**   kilometers

hints.content: To find the total course length, we can add the fractions:  $\blueD{\dfrac{5}{4}} + \greenD{\dfrac{95}{4}} + \maroonD{\dfrac{21}{4}}$
Winnie's course was $\dfrac{{121}}{4}$ kilometers long.  This can also be written as ${30\dfrac{1}{4}}$ kilometers.

question.content: Sven is reading a book while on vacation.  So far, he has read $\dfrac{1}{6}$ of the book. He wants to finish $\dfrac{3}{6}$ of the book by the end of vacation.  **What fraction of the book does Sven want to read between now and the end of vacation?**

hints.content: To find the fraction of the book that Sven wants to read, we can subtract the fraction he has read from the total amount he wants to read:  $\blueD{\dfrac{3}{6}} - \greenD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-sixths to six-sixths with tick marks at every one-sixth unit. A red dot is on two-sixths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at three-sixths moves left along the number line, pointing to the two-sixths mark. Above the arrow is a label minus one-sixth.

hints.content: Sven wants to read another $\dfrac{2}{6}$ of his book while he is on vacation.  We can also write this as $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of his book.

question.content: Kira worked $\dfrac{87}{100}$ of the problems on her math test in the first hour.   After the second hour, she had worked $\dfrac{97}{100}$ of the problems.  **What fraction of the problems did she work in the second hour?**

hints.content: To find what fraction of the test Kira finished in the second hour, we can subtract the fraction that she had finished after $1$ hour from the fraction that she had finished after $2$ hours:  $\blueD{\dfrac{97}{100}} - \greenD{\dfrac{87}{100}}$
Kira finished $\dfrac{10}{100}$ of the problems in the second hour.  This can also be written as $\dfrac{1}{10}$ of the problems.

question.content: James and Karlee caught a lizard in their backyard.  Its length from head to the end of the tail is $\dfrac{3}{5}$ meters, and the length of its tail is $\dfrac{1}{5}$ meters.  **What is the length of the lizard without the tail?**   meters

hints.content: To find the length of the lizard without the tail, we can subtract the length of the tail from the total length of the lizard.    $\blueD{\dfrac{3}{5}} - \greenD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fifths to five-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit. A red dot is on two-fifths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at three-fifths moves left along the number line, pointing to the two-fifths mark. Above the arrow is the label minus one-fifth.

hints.content: The length of the lizard without the tail is $\dfrac{2}{5}$ meters.

question.content: Pedro is supposed to practice piano for $\dfrac{4}{6}$ of an hour every day.  Today, he has practiced for $\dfrac{2}{6}$ of an hour.  **What fraction of an hour does he still need to practice?**

hints.content: To find how much more time Pedro needs to practice, we can subtract the amount of time he has practiced from the total time he needs:  $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{6}} - \greenD{\dfrac{2}{6}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-sixths to six-sixths with tick marks at every one-sixth unit. A red dot is on two-sixths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-sixths moves left along the number line, pointing to the two-sixths mark. Above the arrow is the label minus two-sixths.

hints.content: Pedro still needs to practice $\dfrac{2}{6}$ of an hour.  This can also be written as $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of an hour.

question.content: Isa is allowed to play video games for $\dfrac{5}{3}$ hours each day.  She has already played for $\dfrac{4}{3}$ hours today.  **What fraction of an hour does Isa have left to play video games today?**

hints.content: To find how much more time Isa has to play, we can subtract the amount of time she has already played from the total time she is allowed.    $\blueD{\dfrac{5}{3}} - \greenD{\dfrac{4}{3}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to six-thirds with tick marks at every one-third unit. A red dot is on one-third. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at five-thirds moves left along the number line, pointing to the one-third mark. Above the arrow is the label minus four-thirds.

hints.content: Isa still has $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of an hour left to play video games.

question.content: Together, Lulu and Jessica ate $\dfrac{7}{10}$ of a pizza.  Lulu ate $\dfrac{4}{10}$ of the pizza.   **What fraction of the pizza did Jessica eat?**

hints.content: To find how much pizza Jessica ate, we can subtract the amount of pizza Lulu ate from the total both Jessica and Lulu ate together.    $\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}} - \greenD{\dfrac{4}{10}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-tenths to ten-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit. A red dot is on three-tenths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at seven-tenths moves left along the number line, pointing to the three-tenths mark. Above the arrow is the label minus four-tenths.

question.content: Stacy is measuring milk to make pancake batter.  The recipe calls for $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of a jug of milk.  She has $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a jug now.    **How much more milk does she need?**   of a jug

hints.content: To find the amount of milk that is needed, we can subtract the amount of milk Stacy has from the amount she needs:  $\blueD{\dfrac{3}{4}} - \greenD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fourths to four-fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. A red dot is on two-fourths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at three-fourths moves left along the number line, pointing to the two-fourths mark. Above the arrow is the label minus one-fourth.

hints.content: Stacy needs $\dfrac{2}{4}$ of a jug more milk to make her pancake batter.  This can also be written as $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a jug.

question.content: The table shows the heights of three different plants.  Type of Plant | Height (meters)  - | - | - Tomato | $\dfrac58$ Pepper | $\dfrac38$ Bean | $\dfrac28$  **What is the height of the tomato plant and the bean plant combined?**   meter

hints.content: To find the height of tomato plant and the bean plant combined, we can add.   $\redD{\dfrac{5}{8}} + \blueD{\dfrac{2}{8}}$

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket above the first five parts is labeled five-eighths. A curved bracket above the next two parts is labeled two-eighths. Together the curved brackets are labeled five-eighths plus two-eighths.

hints.content: The height of the tomato plant and the bean plant combined is $\dfrac78\text{ m}$.

question.content: The table shows the amount of apples three friends collected.   ${}$ | Amount (bucket)  - | - | - Fred | $\dfrac56$ Taylor | $\dfrac46$ Amir | $\dfrac16$  **How many buckets of apples did Fred and Taylor pick combined?**   buckets

hints.content: To find the amount of apples Fred and Taylor picked combined, we can add.   $\redD{\dfrac{5}{6}} + \blueD{\dfrac{4}{6}}$

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 6 equal parts, each part labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket above the first five parts of the first bar is labeled five-sixths. A curved bracket above the remaining part of the first bar and the first three parts of the second bar is labeled four-sixths. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled five-sixths plus four-sixths.

hints.content: The amount of apples Fred and Taylor picked combined is $\dfrac96$ of a bucket, or $1 \dfrac12$ buckets.

question.content: The table shows the amount of cake $3$ friends ate.   ${}$ | Amount eaten - | - | - Truett | $\dfrac3{10}$ Charlie | $\dfrac5{10}$ Kathryn | $\dfrac1{10}$  **How much cake did all three friends eat combined?**   cake

hints.content: To find the amount of cake they ate, we can add.  $\redD{\dfrac{3}{10}} + \blueD{\dfrac{5}{10}} + \greenD{\dfrac1{10}}$

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 10 equal parts, each part labeled one-tenth. A curved bracket above the first three parts is labeled three-tenths. A curved bracket above the next five parts is labeled five-tenths. A curved bracket above the next part is labeled one-tenth. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-tenths plus five-tenths plus one-tenth.

hints.content: The amount of cake the three friends ate combined is $\dfrac9{10}$ of the cake.

question.content: The table shows the distance Veronica ran over a week.  Day | Length {km} - | - | - Monday| $\dfrac8{4}$ Tuesday | $\dfrac7{4}$ Thursday | $\dfrac3{4}$ Friday | $\dfrac5{4}$  **How many kilometers did Veronica run on Tuesday and Friday?**   kilometers

hints.content: To find the length Veronica ran, we can add.  $\redD{\dfrac{7}{4}} + \blueD{\dfrac{5}{4}}$

images.alt: Three equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. A curved bracket above all the parts of the first bar and the first three parts of the second bar is labeled seven-fourths. A curved bracket above the remaining part of the second bar and all of the parts of the third bar is labeled five-fourths. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled seven-fourths plus five-fourths.

hints.content: Veronica ran $\dfrac{12}{4}$ of a kilometer on Tuesday and Friday, or $3$ kilometers.

question.content: The table shows the distance Shannon ran over a week.  Day | Length {km} - | - | - Tuesday| $\dfrac5{2}$ Wednesday | $\dfrac6{2}$ Friday | $\dfrac4{2}$ Saturday | $\dfrac1{2}$  **How many more kilometers did Shannon run on Friday than on Saturday?**   kilometers

hints.content: To find the difference Shannon ran, we can subtract.  $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{2}} - \greenD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to four-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit. A red dot is on three-halves. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-halves moves left along the number line, pointing to the three-halves mark. Above the arrow is the label minus one-half.

hints.content: Shannon ran $\dfrac{3}{2}$ of kilometer more on Friday than on Saturday.

question.content: The table shows the heights of three different plants.  Type of Plant | Height (meters)  - | - | - Corn | $\dfrac{19}8$ Pepper | $\dfrac58$ Squash | $\dfrac78$  **How much taller is the tallest plant than the shortest plant?**   meters

hints.content: To find the difference between the two plants, we can subtract.  $\blueD{\dfrac{19}{8}} - \greenD{\dfrac{5}{8}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled eight-eights to twenty four-eighths with tick marks at every one-eighth unit. A red dot is on fourteen-eighths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at nineteen-eighths moves left along the number line, pointing to the fourteen-eighths mark. Above the arrow is the label minus five-eighths.

hints.content: The difference between the tallest and shortest plant is $\dfrac{14}8\text{ m}$, or $1\dfrac34\text{ m}$.

question.content: The table shows the amount of juice $3$ friends drank.    ${}$ | Amount (liters)  - | - | - Owen | $\dfrac5{10}$ Nora | $\dfrac8{10}$ John | $\dfrac3{10}$  **How much more juice did Nora drink than Owen?**   liter

hints.content: To find out how much more juice Nora drank, we can subtract.  $\blueD{\dfrac{8}{10}} - \greenD{\dfrac{5}{10}}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-tenths to ten-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit. A red dot is on three-tenths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at eight-tenths moves left along the number line, pointing to the three-tenths mark. Above the arrow is the label minus five-tenths.

hints.content: Nora drank $\dfrac3{10}$ of a liter more juice than Owen.
